key_points: President Joe Biden emphasizes the importance of ending the COVID-19 pandemic globally.
The U.S. has committed $4 billion to support COVAX and is working to boost global vaccine production.
Biden's administration supports temporarily waiving intellectual property rights for COVID-19 vaccines.
The U.S. has shared over 4 million vaccine doses with Canada and Mexico and will share 80 million doses worldwide by the end of June.
The first 25 million doses will be allocated globally, with at least 75% shared through COVAX.
Approximately 19 million doses will be distributed to Latin America, the Caribbean, South and Southeast Asia, and Africa via COVAX.
Over 6 million doses will be shared directly with countries in need, including Canada, Mexico, India, and the Republic of Korea.
The U.S. aims to save lives and end the pandemic by sharing vaccines without expecting favors or concessions in return.
Biden highlights the role of strong American leadership in ending the pandemic and improving global health security.
Future vaccine distribution plans will be announced as the U.S. continues to combat the spread of COVID-19.
